subject: RE: [junit] Testing package private classes
msgSnippet: ... What this comes down to is that it s different strokes for different folks . Some people hate testing private methods, others don t mind it. Personally, I
messageBody:
Cedric Beust writes:
> Unit testing allows you to test very small portions of
> code in order to catch failures as soon as possible. If
> all you test is public/protected methods, you will miss an
> opportunity to catch a bug in a very fundamental piece of
> your code and you will be wasting time looking for it.

What this comes down to is that it's "different strokes for
different folks". Some people hate testing private methods,
others don't mind it. Personally, I don't have a problem
testing package-level methods, but wouldn't jump through
hoops to test truly-private methods. (Indeed, as I often
have classes with extensive interaction within the package,
this is pretty important)

However, one very good piece of advice is: if you feel a
driving need to test a non-public method, it's a _possible_
sign that you have a new class trying to emerge out of the
current one.

> For example, imagine you are writing a file manager that
> can list your files in several orders (by date, by name,
> etc...) and therefore, makes use of several types of
> algorithms, all private. One day, the program starts
> showing the files in the wrong order.
>
> The sort algorithm is not exposed to anyone, but if you
> unit-test it, you will catch the error much earlier
> instead of starting to investigate, say, your list widget.

Here's an excellent example. :) The sort algorithims are
probably a fairly generic sort of beast that could be made
into seperate classes without any loss of abstraction.
Indeed, that's what the java.util.Comparator interface is
for. So you could then write tests for the comparators
directly.

Again, however, this comes more down to personal preference
than any solid rule. The basics are: unit tests should try
to be very fine grained. This may have the side effect of
increasing visibility of methods as you look closer at the
details.

> Don't be dogmatic about testing: test whatever you think
> can break. And it's okay if it includes private methods.

"Wot 'e said".

Robert.
